text: hi I'm Harsha sanku a partner Solutions
architect with AWS
in this session we are going to look at
hybrid connectivity for VMware Cloud on
AWS multi-region deployments we are also
going to take a look at how to extend
your on-premises connectivity to the AWS
cloud
for those of you who are not familiar
with VMware Cloud on AWS it's a jointly
engineered service that's been developed
by AWS and VMware that gives customers
the ability to run VMware software
defined data centers on AWS Global
infrastructure including all of your
availability zones and regions a
software defined data center comprises
of vsphere vsan and nsxt which is
capable of providing compute storage and
network virtualization this gives
customers the ability to run vsphere
workloads on the AWS cloud
let's jump into it
customers can start by deploying stdc's
one or more stdcs as part of an stdc
group once the httc group is deployed it
automatically Provisions a VMware
Transit Connect that performs the job of
a transitive router in the cloud
enabling high-speed connectivity between
multiple stdcs
now beyond the stdcs to enable
communication to the other AWS workloads
you can use a peering attachment and
connect the VMware transit connect to an
AWS Transit Gateway now Amazon vpcs in
the same region can connect to the AWS
Transit Gateway as you can see here the
vpcs are now able to talk to each other
using the AWS Transit Gateway
whereas the stdcs are able to talk to
each other using the VMware Transit
Connect Now for these vpcs and the sgdcs
to be able to talk to each other we can
leverage the attachment that goes
between the VMware Transit Connect
and the AWS Transit Gateway
now all of this networking happens
within the AWS Cloud now how do we
extend this connectivity back to the
on-prem location so that these workloads
are able to talk to workloads that
resides inside the customer Data Center
as you can see you have an on-premises
environment that is going to Leverage
The AWS Direct Connect service to
establish connectivity back to the AWS
Cloud AWS Direct Connect is a service
that is used to establish high-speed
private connectivity to the AWS Cloud
using AWS Partners there are multiple
options in terms of virtual interfaces
that you will have to create to
establish the connectivity for the
purpose of this architecture we are
going to leverage a Transit whiff that
is going to be terminated
on the direct connect Gateway
once you have a direct connect Gateway
which is basically a global resource
that enables communication to multiply
AWS regions this Direct Connect Gateway
can be associated with an AWS Transit
Gateway
once this communication is established
you have connectivity that is end to end
all the way from your on-premises to the
AWS cloud
now how do you extend this connectivity
to a multi-region deployment just like
you have resources in region a you have
a region B in which you could create one
or more stdcs which in turn will be
connected to a VMware Transit Connect in
region B
so all the httc's in region a can talk
to the VMware Transit connecting region
a and the sgdc's in region B would be
able to talk to the transit connecting
region B
now you can have a peering attachment
that goes back and forth between both
the transit connects in region a and
region B this kind of deployment is used
for customers who want to have
multi-region deployments for like either
production test Dev environments or also
for customers who are looking at
disaster recovery options wherein they
could leverage one of the VMware tools
like the site recovery manager service
or the VMware Cloud Disaster Recovery
Service and designate one of the regions
as the protected region and the other
region as the recovery region and vice
versa now for you to be able to mimic
the architecture in region 1 in Region 2
you can then use the same pairing
attachment on region B to establish
communication to an AWS Transit Gateway
now just like region a you have vpcs in
region B that can talk to the AWS
Transit Gateway in region B similar to
how you establish a connectivity between
VMware Transit connects you can
establish a connectivity between both
the transit gateways
now once this is done to complete the
connectivity you can associate the same
Direct Connect Gateway with the AWS
Transit Gateway in region B this gives
you complete end-to-end connectivity for
both AWS regions back to the on-premises
now as a prerequisite for you to be able
to complete this connectivity from an
stdc perspective all the sddcs will have
to be part of the same VMware cloud and
AWS customer organization
similarly
all the vpcs can be part of the same AWS
customer organization
now there are customers who are looking
to build highly resilient connectivity
between their on-premises and the AWS
Cloud these customers can leverage a
second AWS Direct Connect from a
different partner under different
location to establish connectivity and
now you can use the second AWS Transit
whiff to complete the connectivity to
the direct connect Gateway this is going
to increase the network resiliency for
your on-premises networks I would
recommend watching some of the other
videos that are part of this series to
understand the network connectivity
options including ipsec side to side
vpns thanks for your time I'll see you
on to the next one
